author: Olubode Olusesan
title: Court stops Moro from travelling abroad for treatment
text:
Abba Moro 
Ade Adesomoju, Abuja 
A Federal High Court in Abuja, on Friday, rejected an application by a former Minister of Interior, Abba Moro, seeking permission to travel abroad on health grounds. 
The court had seized the former minister’s passport as part of the bail condition granted him with respect to his ongoing trial for procurement fraud and money laundering. 
The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission arraigned Moro along with some senior officials of the ministry on 11 counts in relation to the ill-fated Nigerian Immigration Service’s recruitment exercise in 2014. 
Moro’s co-accused are a former Permanent Secretary in the ministry, Anastasia Daniel-Nwobia, a deputy director in the ministry, F. O Alayebami, Mahmood Ahmadu (at large), and Drexel Tech Nigeria Limited, a firm that was awarded the recruitment job. 
Moro had, in his application filed by his lawyer, Paul Erokoro (SAN), sought the court’s permission to travel abroad for a medical appointment. 
But in his ruling on Friday, Justice Nnamdi Dimgba, noted that it was too late in March to grant the application, dated December 16, 2016, seeking to meet an appointment scheduled for January 2017. 
“A medical appointment for January 2017 cannot be given in March,” the judge ruled. 
The judge asked Erokoro to update the application, and adjourned until March 21, 2017 for hearing of pending applications.
